div.p: Algiers Charter is a community-based charter network committed to student success in both college and life. Each school is designed to support each child’s academic, social, and emotional journey.

Our approach in education is tailored across each grade level to be engaging, rigorous, and motivating. We believe those qualities are necessary in order for students to develop the critical thinking and core knowledge needed to succeed.

h3.a: Seeking Applications for Algiers Charter Special Education Advisory Council

div.p: Written on Friday, December 20, 2019
Dear Algiers Charter Families:

Act 274 (SB 158) mandates the creation of a Special Education Advisory Council by every school district and charter school or charter network. Algiers Charter is accepting applications for membership on the Special Education Advisory Council. This council will meet at a minimum of three (3) times per year to provide advice and recommendations regarding special education policies, procedures, and resources. Additionally, the SPED Council shall engage in outreach activities to the community to increase the level of knowledge, support, and collaboration concerning special education.
Below includes the groups that can apply to be a part of the Special Education Advisory Council:

ul.li: Parents or legal guardians of SPED students enrolled at an Algiers Charter school
School administrators, Special Education Teachers, and Special Education ParaEducators

Special Education Stakeholders
Adults with disabilities
Self-advocates (high school students with disabilities)
Members of organizations serving students with disabilities
Employers of students with disabilities

h3.a: Landry-Walker Black Box Ensemble & Theatre Department Presents "A Raisin in the Sun" in Celebration of its 60th Anniversary

div.p: Written on Friday, December 6, 2019
Algiers Charter Schools
Ambria Washington, Director of Communications

p.span: This email address is being protected from spambots. You need JavaScript enabled to view it.

strong.style: background-color: inherit; color: inherit; font-family: inherit; font-size: 1rem;
background-color: inherit; color: inherit; font-family: inherit; font-size: 1rem;
text-align: center; background-color: inherit; color: inherit; font-family: inherit; font-size: 1rem;

p.strong: LANDRY-WALKER BLACK BOX ENSEMBLE & THEATRE DEPARTMENT PRESENTS

strong.style: text-align: center; background-color: inherit; color: inherit; font-family: inherit; font-size: 1rem;
text-align: center; background-color: inherit; color: inherit; font-family: inherit; font-size: 1rem;

p.em: Landry-Walker’s Theatre Production of "A Raisin in the Sun'" hits the stage on December 12th and 13th

a.strong: Click here to view the flyer

div.p: NEW ORLEANS – (Dec. 6, 2019) Landry-Walker High School Black Box Ensemble & Theatre presents the full, original text version of Lorraine Hansberry’s A Raisin in the Sun to kick off its 2019-2020 theatre season and honor the 60th Anniversary of the first stage play written by a black woman and produced on Broadway.

The show will run from Thursday, December 12th through Friday, December 13th at Landry-Walker High School at 7 p.m. (1200 LB Landry Avenue, New Orleans, LA 70114) inside the Rev. Arthur Wadsworth Jr. Theatre. Directed by Theatre Instructor, Jyna Roots-Tilton, the show is composed of eight student-actors in grades 9th-12th and features three guest-actors staring in the roles of Lena, Travis and Lindner.

In the story of A Raisin in the Sun, Hansberry reveals to countless audiences around the world that she was not only a brilliant writer but a woman who was well ahead of her time. The classic work expressed through the art of theatre by our high school students explores a myriad of themes that are still relevant today, including, but not limited to family dynamics, housing discrimination, race relations, pan Africanism and gender roles; all of which seamlessly fall under the overarching theme of dreams.

A Raisin in the Sun is the answer to the question posed by the great poet Langston Hughes, “what happens to a dream deferred?” Most importantly, the storyline gives the world an up-close, honest look at the home and family life of a black man.

The Landry-Walker Black Box Ensemble is thrilled to open up its doors to the community to an excellent performance. Both evening shows will be followed by a VIP reception, which will include light refreshments, a cast meet and greet, signed posters, a live student jazz ensemble and a student art exhibit celebrating the anniversary of the historical play.

ul.li: ·December 13, 2019- 7:00 PM Closing Night/Divine Nine Night/VIP Reception

div.em: *Student-actors are available for interviews upon request. For interviews or b-roll, please contact the Director of Communication, Ambria Washington at 504-330-9595.

h3.a: Algiers Charter Partners with Non-Profit to Bring Innovative Learning Explorer STEM Lab to Martin Behrman

div.p: Written on Tuesday, November 19, 2019
Algiers Charter Schools
Ambria Washington, Director of Communications

p.span: This email address is being protected from spambots. You need JavaScript enabled to view it.

img.style: display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;

b.style: background-color: inherit; color: inherit; font-family: inherit; font-size: 1rem;
background-color: inherit; color: inherit; font-family: inherit; font-size: 1rem;

p.b: ALGIERS CHARTER PARTNERS WITH NON-PROFIT TO BRING INNOVATIVE LEARNING EXPLORER “STEM” LAB TO MARTIN BEHRMAN

div.p:
NEW ORLEANS – (Nov. 19, 2019) Algiers Charter launches a partnership with non-profit, Learning Undefeated, to bring life-changing STEM education and career opportunities to Martin Behrman middle schoolers.
The Verizon Innovative Learning explorer lab, which is run by Learning Undefeated, is a shared immersive learning experience that combines movie-quality video, special effects, and hands-on educational gaming to create a learning environment that gets kids excited about science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) – right in the school’s parking lot.
“Several of our Martin Behrman middle schoolers were able to take a break from their normal class routine last week and join in on some STEM-related fun on the Explorer lab,” said Algiers Charter CEO, Tale’ Lockett. “Our goal for our students at Algiers Charter is to immerse our students in all things STEM, so they can be confident in going into any STEM-related career in their future, so these partnerships are vital to us.”
The program travels to different cities across the country and is serving New Orleans students for the 2019-2020 school year. It’s run by three Learning Undefeated instructors who are experienced in science education and understand the importance of bringing hands-on activities to inspire students.
“In the classroom, students work as a team to engineer rovers and problem solve how they can create a rover that travels the furthest distance,” said Learning Undefeated Education Program Manager, Benedetta Naglieri. “On the explorer lab, students blast off into space and are aerospace engineers, building and improving virtual rovers on Mars to complete a mission. The program gives students first-hand experience of what it is like to be an engineer, using the engineering process, and how important it is to work cohesively as a team.”
Learning Undefeated and Verizon’s Innovative Learning Explorer Lab is expected to return to Martin Behrman School in the Spring.
